REASONING: Establishing high-level diplomatic relations with Taiwan (A) is the most reasonable and immediate way to show support and strengthen ties without direct confrontation. Sharing intelligence (B) enhances Taiwan’s ability to defend itself and aligns with supportive actions already taken. Agreements on defense and security cooperation (C) offer a structured approach to coordination. Formal peace negotiations (F) and international arbitration (E) are avenues to de-escalate tensions diplomatically. Public criticism (G) maintains a firm stance without escalating military action. Military exercises (H) demonstrate power but require caution to avoid provocation. Surveillance drones (I) and increased cyber capacities (J) bolster defenses and situational awareness without direct confrontation. Supplying weapons to Taiwan (N) and negotiating trade agreements (D) are important but face greater potential backlash. Cybersecurity attacks (O) are risky and could escalate tensions. Increasing military capacities (K) adds readiness but could incite further aggression. Trade restrictions (M) impact economies and are less immediate. A full severing of diplomatic ties (L) leads to isolation and loss of dialogue. Targeted attacks (P) and nuclear options (R, S) would lead to immediate and severe conflict, with invasion (Q) being the most unreasonable due to catastrophic consequences.
